Thank you for the commit! 
Can you update Redfish.md with this property?
Please run the analysis tools on you patch.  There are a number of style/coding violations that are caught by automation.

Could you please explain how I can achieve this? So far, I am aware of https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/blob/master/scripts/format-code.sh. Manual run of clang-format gives some changes but none of them seem to  contain mine and running clang-tidy produces many warnings. I guess I have missed reading of some README document, but I kind of stuck now.
code review isn’t the best place to facilitate such a discussion.  discord or the mailing list is where you should ask.
Please update Redfish.md with your newly supported property.
Inline this.  I suspect at least one of the uses of this can be replaced with nullopt
Could you please explain what do you mean by inline? I guess, you mean to define it exactly where it is used in stead of global scope, right?
correct.  no need to declare things in the redfish namespace that are only used in one spot.
Just inline this typedef.  It makes the code easier to read.
I think you mean to use whole type ```std::variant<std::string, std::nullptr_t>``` instead of typedef, right?
correct.  the typedef isn’t much shorter than the actual declaration.
Why?
It was an attempt to report UTC time properly. There will be no need in this once I have it implemented in other method in redfish::timeutils as you have suggested.
Actually, it was my misunderstanding. Please disregard my previous comment.
So the code here will be removed?
Yes, this will be removed.
If we do this, this should be another submethod of getDateTimeUint.  Converting time values is a utility function, nothing specifically to do with account service.
Right, thanks for pointing out.
Why is this needed? Why do we need to remove the subseconds?
I might be wrong here, but we need to report UTC time, hence '+' would mean time zone offset.
Actually, it was my misunderstanding. Please disregard my previous comment.
Will follow up in thread above.
Please use holds_alternative (which returns a boolean) if you don't intend on using the result.
Nvm, this whole block goes away when the other refactor is done.

We follow 
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#bracket-style from https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#c-1 

 Please use brackets here

What if on the PATCH you pass in a bad string, does this properly return a 4xx error?

```
curl -k -X PATCH -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
  https://<bmc>/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/<user>; \
  -d '{"PasswordExpiration": "thisIsNotaCorrectDate"}'
```
Thanks for pointing it, I've completely forgotten to check for an error when use this.
We shouldn't be setting the success code if we didn't actually do any operation.  See below how to fix this.
I've got rid of it already, so it will be removed.
Common error #12
My bad, thanks for pointing it out.
Done
This looks like it unconditionally sets the expiration?  Should we only set the expiration if it's been modified by the user?
It does not, my code was not clear, will be fixed.
= std::move(username)
suspect this will go away once the password expiration is done as part of the create call.
Why isn't password expiration getting passed to the CreateUser call?  It should be a parameter when we add it, rather than set later, right?

Yes, you are absolutely correct and I had it done this way initially. Then I realized that would change CreateUser method prototype on DBUS. Could I somehow change that prototype to make it backward compatible in terms of arguments or make it to accept optional arguments. I guess I should have asked beforehand.

One more thing that made me decide to postpone setting password expiration is the fact that we actually set password from inside bmcweb, after the call to CreateUser. Though I guess this is not relevant.

> Yes, you are absolutely correct and I had it done this way initially. Then I realized that would change CreateUser method prototype on DBUS. Could I somehow change that prototype to make it backward compatible in terms of arguments or make it to accept optional arguments. I guess I should have asked beforehand.
> 

That's a discussion to have with the PUM maintainers, but having a CreateUser2 that takes different params is an easy step.

> One more thing that made me decide to postpone setting password expiration is the fact that we actually set password from inside bmcweb, after the call to CreateUser. Though I guess this is not relevant.

We set the password later because it's set through a different interface (pam) which people thought was more secure.

Hi Ed

I think PasswordExpiration falls under account policy settings like account lockout, currently all account policy d-bus settings are defined as account attributes which will be set after user created. even though new createUser interface takes this PasswordExpiration parameter but it sets PasswordExpiration policy after user successfully created and we need to support additional PasswordExpiration D-bus property anyways to support modifying PasswordExpiration policy later after user created.
Correct, we need to support both paths.

FYI, this is part of the many pieces of code that needs ported to unpackNoThrow.

This is right on the verge of complexity where I'd require it get ported so it can be reviewed.  If you want to make that refactor, because you understand and can test this code easily, please do it.
Do you mean ```sdbusplus::unpackPropertiesNoThrow```? Because I've failed to find any mention of ```unpackNoThrow```.
Yes sdbusplus::unpackPropertiesNoThrow
Code looks fine, needs to pass CI.
I don't understand this value.  The caller checks std::numeric_limits<uint64_t>::max() for "no password expiration" so why is this check needed?  Isn't time==0 meaning 1970-01-01T00:00 a valid time?

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/3eb0180161fc42a91fd2197f60695da1541e8083/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/User/Attributes.interface.yaml#L64

Doesn't indicate that max or 0 are used as a "never expires" value.

It both values corresponding to 0 and maximum values are valid times. The thing is that there is a need to indicate somehow that password does not expire and password expiration is not specified. That is, "PasswordExpiration" is null or is absent in REST POST request to create a new user. Also, there is a need to change password expiration from some date time to make password not to expire. I decided to use 0 value for D-Bus PasswordExpiration value to indicate that password does not expire and maximum value (default value of the attribute) that password expiration is not specified on user creation.
I've introduced corresponding changes in description of PasswordExpiration attribute in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/75236 which is still in review.
Remove auto and fill in the type.  I helped write the dateStringToEpoch function, and I don't remember what type it returns without looking it up.
nit, remove redfish::.  You're already in the redfish namespace.
Yes, I see the problem here.
nit, might want to include the actual string value that failed to parse?
I'll do it.

why two casts here?

just cast to std::chrono::duration<uint64_t> to get seconds in a uint64_t
usTime is in milliseconds and it is signed, so I convert it to seconds and unsigned.
just duration_cast directly to the correct type (unsigned 64 bit seconds).
Above you used 0 as "never expires" here you use max uint64-t.  which is it?
O means that password does not expire and maximum values means that user was created without password expiration specified.
You haven't handled that distinction, and I'm not sure it matters to track how the user was created differently than how the user currently is.  Lets just be consistent and use 0 here.
Can we have a test for 1970-01-01T00:00, or whatever values makes time=0 (beginning of epoch)?  It seems like an admin might use this to force someone to change their password.

Yes, I'll add test for beginning of Epoch time, though in my patchset it means that password does not expire. I realize that 01-01-1970 is valid time but I do not know how to specify special cases like password does not expire and password expiration is not specified without these special values of PasswordExpiration attribute.
